pullRequest.body:
The goal of this PR is to move the requirement for finiteness further down the import graph. To do so, this PR splits `Filter/Bases.lean` into three files:
* `Bases/Defs.lean`: definition of `FilterBases`, `IsFilterBasis`, `Filter.HasBasis`
* `Bases/Basic.lean`: basic results (those do not depend on finiteness)
* `Bases/Finite.lean`: results that depend on finiteness

We then use this split to splits `AddTopBot/Basic.lean` further, moving out finiteness to `AtTopBot/Finite.lean` and upstreaming results on products to `AtTopBot/Prod.lean`.

This should hopefully reduce the amount of finiteness that is needed to work with topological and metric spaces.


---

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

I'm completely happy with splitting filter files, but I must say the motivation sounds weird to me. I would expect finiteness to be part part of the common base that we need everywhere to do anything meaningful.

You're right that we do indeed need the notion of finiteness and cardinality in order to define e.g. metric spaces. But we don't need all the theory that Mathlib contains about finiteness, like for example `Finset.sum` is not used at all there. We can move those dependencies down quite a bit further. And that gives a considerable reduction: a couple hundred transitive imports in some files.

> we don't need all the theory that Mathlib contains about finiteness, like for example `Finset.sum`

`Finset.sum` sounds like a bad example to make this point, since it is also algebra, which basic topology indeed shouldn't depend on.

> algebra, which basic topology indeed shouldn't depend on.

True! Unfortunately `fun_prop` imports group theory via `Mathlib.Lean.Meta.RefinedDiscrTree.Pi` -> `Mathlib.Algebra.Group.Pi.Basic`...
I thought this was to be avoided by splitting those basic algebra files into notation/actual algebra?
True. I'll bump that up a bit higher on my todo list.
Okay, so I do think the split in this PR is morally worth doing, but I am not sure about the specifics yet. I want to see us get rid of algebra before trying to get rid of finiteness.

> Okay, so I do think the split in this PR is morally worth doing, but I am not sure about the specifics yet. I want to see us get rid of algebra before trying to get rid of finiteness.

Sorry, I don't understand why that should hold up this.
In any case, we now also have #22499.
Great! Let's wait until #22499 is merged then. We'll have a better idea of the import reductions that the change in the current PR rakes off.
We can almost put `assert_not_exists Monoid` here, except `Mathlib.Tactic.Measurability` needs to specially handle `npowRec`...
Confusion?
Nope, apparently the extra line made the `longFile` linter complain. (Maybe there's a `<` in the code that should be a ``?)

```suggestion
theorem eventually_atBot_prod_self' [Nonempty ] [Preorder ] [IsDirected  (  )]
```
Can you make clear what the difference between `Bases.Defs` and `Bases.Basic` is? Would you mind moving this split to a later PR, so that we can assess its standalone import reduction?

There's the goal of having a spine of `Defs` files that only contain the minimal theory needed for the next definition. I suppose there isn't much reason to keep the split in this case, since `Order.Filter.Bases.Defs` is only imported in `Order.Filter.Bases.Basic`. I'll merge the two.

pullRequest.title: chore(Order/Filter): split `Filter/Bases.lean`

I'm completely happy with splitting filter files, but I must say the motivation sounds weird to me. I would expect finiteness to be part part of the common base that we need everywhere to do anything meaningful.

You're right that we do indeed need the notion of finiteness and cardinality in order to define e.g. metric spaces. But we don't need all the theory that Mathlib contains about finiteness, like for example `Finset.sum` is not used at all there. We can move those dependencies down quite a bit further.
